image.altText: Karen Payne in Sydney sitting at a park bench looking into the distance.

props.synopsis: Two federal ombudsmen have joined forces to launch a scathing review of the Australian Tax Office and call on government agencies to act more fairly when they chase people for debts.

title.children: 'You can't have a one size fits all': ATO told it's being unfair to taxpayers it's chasing for old debts

image.altText: People stand on the far side of a river bank, looking cold on a grey day as the brown water cuts off a road.

props.synopsis: The southern states could be in for a wet Easter weekend as record-breaking rains inundating central Australia are expected to move south.

title.children: Record outback rains could move south this Easter

image.altText: A yellow boat in the ocean with two people standing at the front

props.synopsis: Police say one person has died and two people are still missing after a fishing boat with five people onboard capsized near Port Lincoln yesterday. A man and a youth were found on a reef nearby and are being treated in hospital.

title.children: One person found dead, search continues for two missing after fishing boat capsizes in South Australian waters

image.altText: Tamara Oudyn sits at the newsdesk, with a film of distortion covering her face.

props.synopsis: An estimated 4.9 million Australians battle through the debilitating pain of migraines. But despite estimates the condition costs the national economy billions each year, a leading researcher says there's far from enough funding or support.

title.children: If I'm getting a migraine while reading the news, my face is a dead giveaway

image.altText: Two  women walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters, with the building's name prominent in the background.

props.synopsis: Despite the brutal round of interest rate hikes, people are still holding onto their jobs — and the unpredictable nature of the real world is making a mockery of economics textbooks. Is it a miracle, or have we arrived at a point where unemployment and inflation can subside together?

title.children: Deal with the devil: Why central banks want you out of work

image.altText: Andrew Giles at a press conference with Clare O'Neil

props.synopsis: The federal government is rushing into parliament legislation making it easier to deport people from immigration detention as it prepares for a deluge of further cases challenging aspects of the nation's immigration framework.

title.children: Government seeks to ram deportation laws through parliament despite crossbench anger

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks inside a church

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has opened the door for negotiations with other parties on religious discrimination, one week after claiming the only way forward was to gain support from the opposition.

title.children: Prime Minister willing to negotiate on religious discrimination

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Chaos in the House of Representatives
Question Time begins with a nuclear dig at Dutton
PM willing to negotiate on religious discrimination

image.altText: A brunette woman looks at a man

props.synopsis: There are no two ways about it — cancer is an absolute dog of a thing. When I was diagnosed I got to choose when I told people and like Princess Catherine, making sure my little family unit is travelling OK has been my highest priority, writes Sinéad Mangan.

title.children: Since my cancer diagnosis I've experienced another C-word: compassion

image.altText: Aircraft flying against blue sky.

props.synopsis: A Qantas flight lands safely in Perth after passengers hear a "large bang" and pilots are forced to shut down one of the plane's engines on their descent, with engineers now inspecting the Airbus A330-200.

title.children: Mid-air scare for Qantas passengers as engine shut down after 'loud bang' on Melbourne-Perth flight

image.altText: An aerial view of the Stuart Highway, south of the township of Elliott.

props.synopsis: A man whose body was found near a major highway in the Northern Territory outback likely died after falling from a moving vehicle while intoxicated, NT Police says.

title.children: NT Police suspects man died near outback highway after falling from vehicle while drunk

image.altText: The red moutain range is shrouded in grey low hanging cloud above the brown flowing Todd River.

props.synopsis: Cattle stations around Alice Springs celebrate after consistent rain rejuvenates parched land at the weekend and the Todd River flows — a rare sight.

title.children: 'Fluorescent' green grass brightens red desert after heavy rainfall in southern NT

image.altText: A close up looking over the shoulder of a woman using her mobile phone on the platform of the train station.

props.synopsis: Noticed less political content in your Instagram feed lately? It's a deliberate move by the social media giant to stop "proactively" recommending political content posted on accounts users don't follow — but experts say the move could impact democracy.

title.children: Seeing less political content on Instagram? It's a deliberate move from Meta, which experts say could impact democracy

image.altText: A man walks up cement steps past a map on a wall

props.synopsis: Evergrande's founder is barred for life from China's financial markets after the company allegedly falsified its revenue — here's what we know so far.

title.children: 'Market darling' Evergrande's $120 billion fraud accusation could have far reaching consequences for Australia. Here's what we know

image.altText: A close-up shot of Donald Trump's face, with an annoyed expression.

props.synopsis: A New York court extends a deadline and slashes the amount of money Donald Trump must pay as bond to avoid having his assets seized, as another court orders a separate criminal trial to go ahead next month.

title.children: Donald Trump has a win and a loss as New York courts rule in separate cases

image.altText: A phone screen displaying the WhatsApp app

props.synopsis: Russian officials summon a top Australian official in Moscow for a please explain over a social media post describing the country's presidential election as a "flagrant violation of international law".

title.children: Furious Russians summon Australian official over social media post criticising election

image.altText: The Crown casino logo is emblazoned on a colourful sign.

props.synopsis: Crown Resorts keeps its monopoly casino licence in Melbourne as the Victorian regulator makes its decision public, while the Australian share market is trading lower. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Victorian gambling regulator allows 'a very different Crown' to keep casino licence, ASX falls after Wall Street slides

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Banks, real estate stocks drag Australian shares lower
Tax office criticised for resurrecting old debts
Premier Investments mulls demerger of Smiggle, Peter Alexander brands

image.altText: Sean "Diddy" Combs wearing a white suit jacket.

props.synopsis: Properties in Los Angeles and Miami belonging to hip hop giant Sean "Diddy" Combs have been searched by US Homeland Security Investigations agents as part of an ongoing-sex trafficking investigation, according to anonymous law enforcement officials.

title.children: Homeland Security agents raid Sean 'Diddy' Combs's properties as part of sex-trafficking probe

image.altText: A ferocious-looking crocodile inside a cage.

props.synopsis: A Queensland man says the saltie "had a go" at him while he was mowing the lawn and ate three of his neighbour's chickens. After months "on edge", residents were relieved to see the big predator captured.

title.children: 3.9m stalker croc caught after terrorising river residents for months

image.altText: Video of dappled sunlight shining through giant underwater kelp forest

props.synopsis: Tucked away in a picturesque bay on the Tasman Peninsula is a precious underwater field of giant kelp that's thriving thanks to a team of determined scientists.

title.children: In this picturesque Tasmanian bay, marine scientists are bringing a once-lost habitat back to life

image.altText: a suspect in the shooting attack at the Crocus City Hall

props.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says last week's deadly attack on a concert hall near Moscow was conducted by Islamist militants but the shooting fits with a wider campaign of intimidation by Ukraine.

title.children: Putin says Islamist militants carried out terror attack, claims shooting fits with Ukraine intimidation

image.altText: A drone hovers while a green laser appears pointed at it.

props.synopsis: Defence has for the first time awarded a multi-million-dollar contract to a Melbourne company to trial its "directed energy" technology as a way of combating unmanned aerial vehicles.

title.children: Defence to trial drone-killing lasers that use advanced 'directed energy' technology

image.altText: Nina crouches beside a brown dog

props.synopsis: Like the Princess of Wales, mum-of-three Nina Di Santo was not in the age group of concern for cancer. Her diagnosis is classified as "early onset" and experts say there is an increase in the number of younger people impacted by the disease.

title.children: Nina's symptoms didn't raise any red flags because she thought she was too young to have bowel cancer

image.altText: A family at a young man's brithday dinner. He has cake and silver balloon shaped in the number 16.

props.synopsis: The teenager took part in a three-year Queensland Health pilot study using whole genome sequencing of children with rare conditions.

title.children: After 16 years, Dominic's family finally know what to call the rare condition he's been living with since birth

props.synopsis: The NSW Building Commissioner has directed the developer of the apartments to fix millions of dollars worth of defects before they are handed over to buyers — but Tracey Kokden would rather get her money back and "move on".

title.children: Buyers stuck in 'nightmare' as beleaguered apartment development delayed again

image.altText: Smoke billows from rugged terrain

props.synopsis: Authorities have spent a third night battling a blaze near Waroona and Pinjarra, south of Perth, as an emergency warning is downgraded.

title.children: Hopes residents can begin to return home as devastating WA bushfire contained

image.altText: The two actors, dressed in 70s-styled striped tops and jeans, stare into each other's eyes sitting on a couch.

props.synopsis: Timothy Conigrave's 1995 memoir is an absolutely devastating story of Australia's AIDS epidemic — but its stage adaptation centres joy and love.

title.children: This classic gay Australian love story is being re-imagined by an (almost) all-queer cast

image.altText: People sit behind a desk with their hand raised in a vote

props.synopsis: The UN Security Council demands an immediate ceasefire between Israel and Palestinian militants Hamas, as well as the immediate and unconditional release of all hostages, as the US abstains from the vote on the resolution.

title.children: UN Security Council calls for ceasefire in Gaza during Ramadan

image.altText: Victor sits on a bench with his young son King George, both smling in front of a colourful painted mural.

props.synopsis: When Manisha Gazula started teaching at one of Australia's most disadvantaged schools, nine in 10 students were moving on to high school with sub-par reading skills. Now the students are outperforming the "good schools" and "punching above their weight".

title.children: Students at one of Australia's most disadvantaged schools now outperforming the 'good schools'

image.altText: The Chinese flag sits alongside the American flag

props.synopsis: US and British officials have filed charges, imposed sanctions, and called out Beijing over a sweeping cyber espionage campaign that allegedly hit millions of people and Foreign Minister Penny Wong has described as "malicious" and "unacceptable".

title.children: China accused of orchestrating cyber espionage campaign affecting millions

image.altText: A bald man in a suit with his hands clasped on a desk

props.synopsis: Australia's secrecy laws were under the microscope on Monday as a special hearing opened in Canberra.

title.children: Foreign intelligence operatives posing as journalists, ASIO boss warns

image.altText: Green wavy hills with mountains and sky in the background

props.synopsis: Our ancestors left Africa some 70,000 years ago, but it took them thousands of years to make it to Europe or Asia. A DNA study may shed light on where they ended up during this 'long pause'.

title.children: 'A very big question in human evolution': Where did our ancestors go after leaving Africa?
